pros: Nice co workers. Clean hospital
cons: Pay could be higher. Purposeful tight scheduling to save money that adds unnecessary stress to job.

pros: The people I work with are awesome
cons: There is some shady things that go on with higher ups

pros: Good health, eye and dental insurance. Good Breakfast and lunch foods and because you're an employee, you will get a small discount on some cafeteria purchases. Garage parking for employees.
cons:
The management is a revolving door. Most of the best people I was working with left that hospital due to the terrible structure there. The last manager I know to be working there, is still currently. If you're ever in their office with them and you have a smart phone, leave it on record. They tried to get me to draw labs off the clock. I'd have put in a complaint if I didn't fall out of work from an anxiety attack and a middle ear infection, I couldn't get any doctors in the network to help me with. 

Insurance there is crap if they want to network together to get you out of the hospital. There's no protective PTO. Only PTO. You can apply for STD (Short Term Disability and/or LTD (Long term Disability) when you've been there about a year. The current manager there wants you to get 4 draws an hour after you've been there a year. After the year mark, they want you to be able to draw 6 an hour. After that 8 an hour. At least stay here no more than 2 months. Get the experience and then get out. 

If you're there by the time you can draw babies, they already know your weaknesses and you'll be out of there before you can transfer. I miss being a phlebotomist and I miss the patient interactions, but if I can't get a job with another company, and there's a potential I could become homeless soon, I'm making sure potential candidates know of what toxicity they're walking into. If I could report them to the BBB, I would. 

There's this odd feeling, when you go to numerous Southwest ENT specialists and a handful of Kettering On Demand doctors and they all fail to give antibiotics eardrops for an ear infection. I can see where hospitals can be a potential problem with sex trafficking or even black market sales. The hospitals have all your information. If you have a disorder or a disability, they could use that to their advantage to cause you to stay sick, drop out of work so you can't get work and become homeless. I was a very good worker. 

There on time. Treated and trained the other phlebotomists well. Was bullied and punched in the side of my ribcage by a nurse I absolutely didn't know. I didn't do anything or know anyone there to deserve that kind of treatment. There was a lot of extra work put onto the staff while management racks up enough pto, they're only in the office 4 days a week. There's more dumped onto the little guy, so there's no teamwork at all like the billboards claim. 

Also, you basically can't get an exemption with the covid vaccine. I tried to do a medical exemption and a religious exemption. For anyone who needs a genuine Christian religious exemption: Use the commandment on theft. They're stealing your right to keep your body as a temple from a foreign vaccine. 

Use the words "covid vaccine" throughout the whole religious exemption form. If you just put the word vaccine on the religious exemption form, they will turn down the exemption, claiming that it sounds like an exemption from all vaccines, when the exemption form clearly states exemption from the covid vaccine. You really have to be very specific to include the word covid or else they will deny your religious exemption.

pros: Opportunity for gaining nursing experience is abundant
cons: While trying to promote a positive culture, the network more or less promotes a put on a happy face and bear it all atmosphere. Employees are expected to perform at 100% at all times while wearing a smile but that is difficult to do in an environment where you are singled out for presenting challenges to management. Employees are pretty much told, here is what is expected of you no matter what and if you can't comply, then tough luck. Now instead of taking feedback from employees that are on the front line and finding some sort of compromise with them, they are paying sign on bonuses up to $45,000, dealing with massive turn over, and paying travel nurses significantly more than they would a nurse that they hired on full-time.

pros: The people are great here!
cons: There are none to speak of

pros: Two hour flex-time given for appointments, etc. with prior notification. Work independently, with little supervision during daily work activities. Opportunity to work remotely if meeting productivity and quality requirements.
cons: -Forced Overtime for months. This is not optional (and no incentive is given), and it was not "here or there," or if/when the department is behind, but literally for MONTHS at a time!!! Two summers in a row, coders were forced to work OT, and it is still happening regularly! -Vacation, sick days, personal days, and holidays all come from accrued PTO hours. -No paid Holidays, although KHN recognizes the 6 major holidays, you either have to use your "accrued PTO" to get paid for the holiday, go without pay, or work the holiday. -Only two people within one coding department are able to request PTO or be off on any given day, making it difficult to get the day(s) off when wanted/needed. In addition, you cannot request time off in advance unless you have already banked/accrued the PTO hours. -Another words, you cannot request PTO for schedule time off, months in advance for future dates (planned vacation/cruise etc.), because you may not have accrued all the hours yet, although, by the time that future date rolls around, you will. -Poor work/life balance. -Gossip and unfair disadvantages/discrimination from management. Harshly reprimanded and targeted individuals, to the brink of quitting or being forced out via continued surveillance and denied access to resources. Thankfully this behavior was not aimed toward me, however I regularly witness this within our department from individuals that think I share the same opinions. It is uncomfortable and unfair to observe and experience the continued stress within the workplace aimed at my fellow team-members. -Coding trainers and team-leads are not on site and are rarely available. Questions and emails may go days before receiving a response, or go unanswered. -No opportunities to grow or cross-train in other HIM/coding roles such as Inpatient, Outpatient, Ambulatory Surgery, Ancillary, ROI, etc.

pros: Hospitals are fairly stable in a poor economy.  People have to have health care and it is one of the last things people give up.  One can transfer to other hospitals in the Adventist network and keep the time in grade eg seniority.  Our hospital is in a beautiful location in the Miami Valley and there are many parks that the city fathers have seen fit to provide for the citizens.  There are several new additions that can enhance the work place and standing in the community, there is going to be a new "heart hospital" to be built in the next 2 years.
cons: It brags of being one of the best in the nation but works very hard at looking good while short changing the quality in many ways.  In the past they have had a person on hire to study, as one example, what specific things a rating organization is asking this year.  We are so obsessed with getting awards and things that bring Status to the organization that the patient can fall thru the cracks, we do not have the staff to give good care in many cases.  The growth of the network is of great importance to the leadership and seems to be more important than the patient.

Employees are encouraged to do the job their way, as long as the job gets done.

Co-workers are fun, hard working for the most part, and very caring. 
Meaningful 
Most days are enjoyable for one reason for another. Whether it's going the extra mile for a patient, or having a laugh with a team member.
cons: The con is that the job often does not get done. Employees are over worked and the job pays little. The benefits are ridiculous. Abenity? Really? Management and other higher ups get paid very, very well. Fred especially. The rest of us? Or rather, the ones at the bottom? As with most large companies the answer is no.

pros: Great benefits working for a large network and continuing education within pays off!
cons: Racial tention with nurses, they hardly ever say hello, just giving order, back stabbing, liars and fake an phony, very rude to STNA's of color, no manors or home training. It's know that upper management feels the same way because it trickles down from the top. The pay is way too low for any STNA to get ahead unless going too school. Hard working aides with little to no gratification for work being done. Way too much work for little pay, too much responsibility, and you can make more working elsewhere.

review_title: benefits of working for a network
pros:
caring supervisors and managers for the most part. 
great facility to work in. 
good patient population usually. 
safe area to work in. 
flexible hours and i can usually rearrange my schedule as needed if i know in advance. 
best part of working for a bigger corporation rather than a small private practice is that I dont have to handle any of the insurance or billing, we have clerical staff that deals with that headache.
cons:
- pay is inflexible, set structure for amount you can start at depending on your degree.  however you can increase it some with Clinical activities and such. 
- as an outpatient therapist i have to rotate to cover weekend hospital shifts every month of so. (some people dont mind this)

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Hamilton, OH
pros: Love the people I work with-nurses, physicians, and other staff. The doctors here do good work, despite some negative reputations within the community. Good team work on the unit. Easy to pick up extra shifts. Pay better then some higher ranked hospitals within the area.
cons: Management constantly changing. Poor leadership within the hospital itself. Limited growth opportunity to move up. It is all about who you know. Not paid based on experience or education. Often short-staffed, be able to manage without PCAs and have heavy patient loads

job_title: Office Assistant II in Centerville, OH
pros: the people that you work with or get to know is a wonderful and inviting environment and place to work you learn early what makes it a good place to work because of the support you get from work
cons: unfair working practice managers sometimes pick on you because where you come from how you talk because of religion you will cant ever get ahead into a more promising job they find ways to skip over you for raises even if means changing your job title.

pros: If you mostly care about the size of your paycheck or are evangelical this is a fine place to work as a hospital.  Seventh Day Adventist folks have a fast track to management.
cons: If you want to be treated with respect, dignity, have personal time that is actual personal, or are secular you will be a fish out of water.  Expect to pray to Jesus at every meeting.  Primary management qualification is devout Christian, not competence or knowledge.

job_title: Employee Health Coordinator in Liberty Township, OH
pros: I had some great managers, Tammye Kaper and Tim Dutton, who understood Employee Health and gave me the freedom to do my job.  They also provided support in various ways.  My team at Kettering Employee Health did an excellent job in handling the large volume of people and paperwork that flowed through our office - my team was amazing.
cons: Work-life balance was sorely lacking and even through Finance would tell me every year that I didn't have enough staff for the workload, I never received any additional help.

pros: They have great benefits and the people that work there are very hard workers.  When working with this company you become a family while working with great people.
cons: The hours are to long and you tend to get tired because of the long hours that your working.  When you want to pick up overtime your to exhausted to to do it.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Kettering, OH
pros: Good benefits with 403(b) matching and profit sharing (some years), PTO accrual increases with seniority.
cons: KHN is a Seventh Day Adventist, so their Sabbath is on Saturday.  They do not really recognize that the majority of their employees have a Sabbath on a different day, nor to they care.  Network down times and such are never done on their Sabbath, we have to give up ours, however.

pros: The support from senior leadership is excellent. The team at KPN (Kettering Physician Network) is committed to placing APPs in areas of practice that they thrive in with support and resources. KPN is very open to feedback/recommendations for improvement, and act on recommendations.
cons: Physicians seem less accustomed to working with APPs within the network. They have all been very open to building a working relationship, but are unfamiliar with our scope of practice, etc. Joining the network without experience as a nurse practitioner, I found the salary to be a bit less than other offers in the area.

review_title: Good environment to work in, great people but a lacking administration when it comes to employee relations.
pros: Very flexible, at least in my department, with my hours.  I love the vacation time set up.  We use PTO (paid time off) and it is accrued bi-weekly, it allows even new employees to accrue 3-4 weeks off after about a year of saving.  Pretty good benefits also and a great group of people to work with.
cons: Unless you want to be a nurse or a scrub tech, they will not help out at all with college tuition.  There may be one or two other positions they will help with, but your choices are very limited.  Doctors can be extremely rude, so if you easily have your feelings hurt, this is not the place for you.  They say they are non-profit, but it is definitely all about the money here.  You give suggestions to administration and it goes right in one ear and out the other.  It can be worse than high school sometimes, if there is a problem between two people, instead of trying to work it out between the two, admin has to always get involved and play secret agent man by talking to others and trying to get dirt on both people.  Can be very frustrating!

review_title: A seriously wonderful bunch of people working for a seriously lacking company.
job_title: Nursing Assistant II in Kettering, OH
pros: I work with some seriously wonderful people. I've went so far as to recommend kmc to my friends and family because I consider it to be a really descent place to work. The days are long and busy, but overall rewarding. Its the employees who make the experience worth while. My manager, in particular, is an angel and I'm thankful she hired me and has such confidence in me.
cons:
I personally would not come here (kmc) for care, but I also have no other hospital to compare it too. My mom, who has worked for various hospitals within the KHN for over 10 years tells me its almost completely different from the place she remembers. Apparently KHN used to be wonderful in almost every way. Now the opposite is true. The employees are stressed because there is simply too much to do and not enough help. It has been my personal experience that several units in the hospital operate short staffed on a daily basis. More work is often given out without added help, or the subtraction of previous assignments. Also, hourly charting is a joke. 
I could go on, but what it boils down to is this: higher pay and better benefits would make us all a lot happier. After, of course, hiring a few dozen more employees.

review_title: Good job but management harasses you all the time.
pros: Good people. Good job. Meaningful work.
cons: Poor management. Content harrasment. Top 10 in nation but can't find one good thing to say. Never recognition for anything we do well, rather only things we do incorrect, (and as top 10 in the nation w press ganey >90%, I feel we're better than they think we are)

pros: Company culture is very strong and TRULY encourages collaboration and employee recognition. Job security is no issue.  Most management in IS has a great set of ideas and wonderful execution (most of the time).  Listens to employee feedback and does it's best to recognize employees and their opinions.  Nationally recognized for outstanding healthcare.  Also, I love working for a not-for-profit.
cons:
Salary salary salary salary...  Most IT analysts elsewhere make 40% more these days.    The company is expanding too rapidly.  ROI for new facilities seems to be crawling and everything else is taking a hit as a result.  KHN seems to have this idea that over-saturating the market will allow it to compete with the other, smaller networks in the region who appear to be far more efficient.  We have 8 hospitals... The next largest in Dayton?  Two.  This is causing very high turnover rates and angering seasoned veterans who have been with the company many years, some to the point of seriously considering going elsewhere.

There are politics, but nothing out of the ordinary, I would say.  

Awkward meetings at times due to the organization being a Seventh-Day-Adventist organization.  Charles Kettering was not SDA, so why should we be forced to adhere to religious doctrine at work?  This isn't a huge issue, but it's a thorn in my side as I am atheist and consider any discussion on religion and politics to be grossly unprofessional in the workplace.

review_title: Hard To Get In The Door - Worth The Wait
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Kettering, OH
pros: Friendly, Compassionate, Competent care for staff and patients alike.
cons: Access to care can be better, as will all healthcare organizations.

review_title: No opportunities for advancement within the organization.
job_title: Manager Physician Recruitment in Dayton, OH
pros: The Quality of the physicians and care givers are second to none. They find great talent and I would feel confident in the abilities of any of the physicians to care for me or my family members
cons: There is a strong bias towards those that are SDA. The employee engagement surveys seem archaic and do not seem to help in improving the overall mission or vision of the network.

pros: My coworkers are wonderful people and I really enjoy coming to work with them. They are very understanding about any situation you may come across and always want to help in any way they can.
cons: I felt overworked because they never had enough staff, but refused to hire more because they didn't want to pay. Then, when the census dropped they cut my hours first. I felt singled out for being the last to join.

pros: Great people (some) but there is one girl in our that has harressed me since day one and yes she gets trouble an then she does it again so no they won't do nothing
cons: Horrible pay and they won't even work with you, I have dream working there since I was a teenager and now I regret it.  The reception gets paid more than I do and I have student loans.

review_title: HR dept and nursing mgmt does not support employees.
pros: The hospital itself is fine and the job itself was decently staffed on the nursing floor and house supervisors doctors and NP/PAs are generally great. It was less stressful than premier health nursing jobs.
cons:
The nursing mgmt and HR department do not honor the disciplinary step system and does not support employees. The overall culture on the nursing floors does not support or parallel the Religious (kind caring good) environment and culture portrayed by the orientation/business process. Very clicky. I thought it was my dream job and I was wrong. I was there 6 months and loved it so much. I was doing very well and was solely responsible for initial life savings decisions on several patients during my time there. I had no problems not even a single tardy, nothing. 
A couple women decided they didn’t like me (I thought everyone liked me enough as I am very helpful, friendly and kind), and they fabricated something to the mgmt. This was confirmed later by 2 employees including a supervisor in a private message to me. The next week NM pulled me into her office asking me strange questions which I answered, to later find that she used those questions against me as she presented information she obtained from my charting and locators. I was as honest as I could be and explained everything in my reasoning and defense (for example, a Med scanner wasn’t working in a certain room and she asked why I manually entered a routine medication prior to my locator showing I entered the room. I explained that I HAD entered the room prior and the locator must have not picked up at that time, as they often do, and that the scanner is broken in this room, and that I have had the patient all week and know them very well and that if there were to be an error or dropped the med it is easy to make the correction in the MAR for accuracy and pt safety of the record. She was not satisfied with anything I said. This is one example of literally at least 10 similar things that are average and common issues in nursing. Also, NO patients were harmed at all or were ever in a possibility of being harmed. She simply did not accept my answers). She told me she “HAD to report it to HR” which is incorrect, as it is up to mgmt to handle such affairs and discipline staff within policy. I was suspended from work 9 days without a phone call from mgmt or HR. I was NEVER contacted by HR, I was never able to explain my side of the story or accusations against me. I was wrongfully terminated and am unable to work in any KHN facility which rules out half the jobs in my city (and I am actually a great nurse who actually wants to be at bedside). I spoke with 2 lawyers who both said this was indeed wrongful termination and defamation of character. They said because OHIO is an at will employment state, that is why there is nothing I can really do unless they prevented me from getting another job elsewhere. 
I also had 3 instances of staff members who openly claimed to be “pagans”/“witches” (no I am not joking), do and say weird things to me without reason or provocation, such as “beware when a witch points at you” after they were pointing at me, and I went to see what they needed. Just weird!! I also had to assist patients that were being neglected by other nurses (alarms and lights going off too long) and yet I did not try to ruin anyone’s livelihood or reputation. I do not recommend anyone to work here at all if any of the other floors are like that one (which close sources say at least 3 others are!)

pros: Low chance for being laid off no support with education assistance other than nursing no advancement or a chance with transferring to other position
cons: No advancement even with education you fine highly qualified people in position that they have out grown because the only advancement is for busing staff
